title: 105_hr4046
content: Restrictions on transfers or discharges of nursing facility residents in case of voluntary withdrawal from Medicaid program. "In case of voluntary withdrawal from Medicaid program, nursing facility can continue providing services but must adhere to restrictions on resident transfers or discharges." The nursing facility can continue providing services after voluntary withdrawal from the Medicaid program, but must follow restrictions on transferring or discharging residents. The nursing facility must continue to follow restrictions on transferring or discharging residents after voluntary withdrawal from the Medicaid program. Upon withdrawal, the facility must inform residents orally and in writing about certain information and obtain a signed acknowledgment from each resident. Upon withdrawal, the facility must inform residents in writing, signed by the individual, and separate from other documents. This does not affect any requirement for advance notice of termination. The facility must inform residents in writing of its intention to terminate the agreement. Information for new residents includes the facility not participating in the program and the ability to transfer or discharge residents. The facility can discharge a resident if they are unable to pay, even if they become eligible for medical assistance. The participation agreement of a facility continues after voluntary withdrawal for receiving payments under the State plan for nursing facility services provided to residents. The participation agreement of a facility continues after voluntary withdrawal for receiving payments under the State plan for nursing facility services provided to residents, maintaining compliance with all applicable requirements of this title, and applying survey, certification, and enforcement authority. The provisions of this subparagraph apply to a significant voluntary reduction in participation under a State plan for a resident entitled to medical assistance under this title. The reduction effective date entitles residents to medical assistance for nursing facility services similar to voluntary withdrawal. The paragraph does not apply to new residents. The Secretary determines that the amendment applies to voluntary withdrawals from participation occurring after the enactment of the Act. A report on implementation is required within 5 years of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must submit a report to Congress within 5 years of the Act's enactment, analyzing the impact of changes in Medicaid reimbursement rates on nursing facilities and their residents. This includes the extent to which facilities withdraw from the Medicaid program and how it affects access to and quality of services. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must submit a report to Congress analyzing the impact of changes in Medicaid reimbursement rates on nursing facilities, including the extent of participation in the program and its effects on access to and quality of services. Recommendations for legislative changes may also be included.
